page.title: 08LANDSCAPE + BUILDINGS
page.content: {LANDSCAPE }The parish of North Leverton with Habblethorpe is the longest named parish in the country. The parish is long and narrow, stretching from the river Trent to the outskirts of Retford, with other parishes, but a short space between. The land generally slopes to the Trent from 20 metres high. Arable farming predominates with cereals, oil seed rape, peas, potatoes, soft fruit and some grass land. The windmill is a feature of the sky line with the churches now dwarfed by the power stations just over the boundary. Roads from West Burton and Cottam power stations connect with the main roads at Retford. The railway line is still used for transporting coal to the power stations.
